text: hi i'm laura moon the director of the
social enterprise initiative and i am
pleased to be here today with the winner
of the hbs business plan contest social
venture track welcome thank you laura
and thanks for having me i'm sudan chana
current hbs 2 class of 2011. our company
is sana care sana care aims to transform
the mobile phone into a medical device
to help people in the developing world
diagnose disease early
every five minutes nearly a hundred
people die from cardiovascular disease
in the developing world
sonicare's mission is to change that
paradigm we want to help people health
workers and physicians diagnose disease
early
such that these deaths can be prevented
early
and how did you come up with the idea
for sonicare
well it was really the realization that
current infrastructure in the developing
one cannot scale to solve the problem of
100 deaths in five minutes there's only
about 11 million hospital beds
and 5 billion people but there's two and
a half billion mobile phones so we
thought what if you could take a mobile
phone and turn it into a medical
diagnostic tool
and that was really the idea that that
we had and we followed that through tell
me why people are not receiving these
services today in the developing world
sure so there's a huge shortage in the
medical
diagnostics available in clinics across
the developing world and that's because
of three reasons first is cost
devices tend to be expensive so
primary clinicians or clinics cannot
afford
second is uh they are complicated to use
uh if you look at tcg it has maybe a
zillion buttons today and you know a
nurse or a physician in the developing
world is simply
not trained to operate such a
complicated piece of equipment and third
interpreting uh data from these devices
so if you again taking the example dcg
you need a specialist to actually
interpret it
and you know without having that on the
ground there's simply even no use for
these devices and that's really that's
the reason why these patients don't have
access to it and how does sonicare
address the solution to those issues so
we take the most ubiquitous device out
there the mobile phone and turn it into
a medical device a mobile phone is
connected so you can send data anywhere
it's simple to use everyone knows how to
use a mobile phone and third is cheap
you know you can get a phone for 50
dollars anywhere in the world and you
know if you plug in a little sensor and
download our software suddenly you have
a medical device that is capable of
performing the most complicated tests
needed to screen for things like heart
disease and diabetes we think that's
pretty revolutionary
and as you
think of your long-term vision can you
tell us a little bit about how you
anticipate the business will grow over
the next several years
sure so our first market is in india
it's a big country and we aim to start
there
and hope to reach nearly 100 clinics by
the end of the year
and then
eventually keep adding not just clinics
but also the number of tests we can
perform with the mobile phone we see the
mobile phone as a diagnostic platform so
you know imagine doing an ultrasound
with it or
and analyzing your glucose levels with
the phone or even using it as a
microscope we think that is
technologically uh technically feasible
and it's a question of whether you can
build a business around it and we think
we can so tell us about the unique
skills and experiences that your team
brings to sonicare sure so our team
combines
experience in designing medical devices
and also experience in distributing
medical devices both of which are
critical to sonicare's success in the
future
so i have experience working as an
engineer and also in commercializing
medical technology in the developing
world whereas my teammates and anika are
really geniuses with designing these
devices that could work reliably and
safely applications so i think we
combine you know the business side and
the technical side to make this happen
and again you know we have
an inherent motivation to make this
happen because you know we've seen a lot
of these problems first-hand growing up
so we really want to make a difference
with our skills um i'm saddam jenner and
i plan to use my mba to transform the
way healthcare is delivered in the
developing world
